thread.title: 渋谷で在日アメリカ人らが入国禁止令へ抗議デモ 安倍首相に注文も【画像多数】
thread.title_full: 渋谷で在日アメリカ人らが入国禁止令へ抗議デモ 安倍首相に注文も【画像多数】

author: 和田千才
title: 渋谷で在日アメリカ人らが入国禁止令へ抗議デモ 安倍首相に注文も【画像多数】
text: ▼「March for an Inclusive America」画像集が開きます▼ Close March for an Inclusive America /   TOKYO, JAPAN - FEBRUARY 12: Participants hold sings and shout slogans during the march to protest against the U.S. President Trump's executive order on immigration in Shibuya district on February 12, 2017 in Tokyo, Japan. Nearly 300 people participated in the march organized by the Alliance for an Inclusive America to protest against the U.S. President Donald Trumps executive order banning the immigration to the United States from several Muslim majority countries. Japanese Prime Minister Abe is currently visiting the United States for his first meeting with President Trump. (Photo by Takashi Aoyama/Getty Images) TOKYO, JAPAN - FEBRUARY 12: A woman holds a signs saying Diversity Makes America Strong at a protest march and rally organised by the Alliance for an Inclusive America group against the perceived anti-Muslim and anti-foreigner immigration policies of President Donald Trump, on February 12, 2017 in Tokyo, Japan. The Alliance of an Inclusive America is a multi-faith non-partisan group. About 250 Americans, other ex-pats and japanese people took part in the march to show people around the world they reject the Executive Order President Trump enacted at the end of January, indefinitely suspending the resettlement of Syrian refugees and temporarily banning people from seven majority Muslim countries from entering the United States. PHOTOGRAPH BY Damon Coulter / Barcroft Images London-T:+44 207 033 1031 E:hello@barcroftmedia.com - New York-T:+1 212 796 2458 E:hello@barcroftusa.com - New Delhi-T:+91 11 4053 2429 E:hello@barcroftindia.com www.barcroftmedia.com (Photo credit should read Damon Coulter / Barcroft Images / Barcroft Media via Getty Images) TOKYO, JAPAN - FEBRUARY 12: People hold sings and shout slogans during the march to protest against the U.S. President Trump's executive order on immigration in Shibuya district on February 12, 2017 in Tokyo, Japan. Nearly 300 people participated in the march organized by the Alliance for an Inclusive America to protest against the U.S. President Donald Trumps executive order banning the immigration to the United States from several Muslim majority countries. Japanese Prime Minister Abe is currently visiting the United States for his first meeting with President Trump. (Photo by Takashi Aoyama/Getty Images) TOKYO, JAPAN - FEBRUARY 12: Crystal Gulotta from Florida poses for a photograph after the march to protest against the U.S. President Trump's executive order on immigration in Shibuya district on February 12, 2017 in Tokyo, Japan. Nearly 300 people participated in the march organized by the Alliance for an Inclusive America to protest against the U.S. President Donald Trumps executive order banning the immigration to the United States from several Muslim majority countries. Japanese Prime Minister Abe is currently visiting the United States for his first meeting with President Trump. (Photo by Takashi Aoyama/Getty Images) TOKYO, JAPAN - FEBRUARY 12: A young girl and boy hold signs near the Yoyogi park before the march to protest against the U.S. President Trump's executive order on immigration in Shibuya district on February 12, 2017 in Tokyo, Japan. Nearly 300 people participated in the march organized by the Alliance for an Inclusive America to protest against the U.S. President Donald Trumps executive order banning the immigration to the United States from several Muslim majority countries. Japanese Prime Minister Abe is currently visiting the United States for his first meeting with President Trump. (Photo by Takashi Aoyama/Getty Images) TOKYO, JAPAN - FEBRUARY 12: Varsha Shankar from India poses for a photograph after the march to protest against the U.S. President Trump's executive order on immigration in Shibuya district on February 12, 2017 in Tokyo, Japan. Nearly 300 people participated in the march organized by the Alliance for an Inclusive America to protest against the U.S. President Donald Trumps executive order banning the immigration to the United States from several Muslim majority countries. Japanese Prime Minister Abe is currently visiting the United States for his first meeting with President Trump. Nearly 300 people participated in the march organized by the Alliance for an Inclusive America to protest against the U.S. President Donald Trumps executive order banning the immigration to the United States from several Muslim majority countries. Japanese Prime Minister Abe is currently visiting the United States for his first meeting with President Trump. Nearly 300 people participated in the march organized by the Alliance for an Inclusive America to protest against the U.S. President Donald Trumps executive order banning the immigration to the United States from several Muslim majority countries. Japanese Prime Minister Abe is currently visiting the United States for his first meeting with President Trump. Nearly 300 people participated in the march organized by the Alliance for an Inclusive America to protest against the U.S. President Donald Trumps executive order banning the immigration to the United States from several Muslim majority countries. Japanese Prime Minister Abe is currently visiting the United States for his first meeting with President Trump. (Photo by Takashi Aoyama/Getty Images) TOKYO, JAPAN - FEBRUARY 12: Participants hold signs and shout slogans during the march to protest against the U.S. President Trump's executive order on immigration in Shibuya district on February 12, 2017 in Tokyo, Japan. Nearly 300 people participated in the march organized by the Alliance for an Inclusive America to protest against the U.S. President Donald Trumps executive order banning the immigration to the United States from several Muslim majority countries. Japanese Prime Minister Abe is currently visiting the United States for his first meeting with President Trump. (Photo by Takashi Aoyama/Getty Images) TOKYO, JAPAN - FEBRUARY 12: A boy holds sing near the Yoyogi park before the march to protest against the U.S. President Trump's executive order on immigration in Shibuya district on February 12, 2017 in Tokyo, Japan. Nearly 300 people participated in the march organized by the Alliance for an Inclusive America to protest against the U.S. President Donald Trumps executive order banning the immigration to the United States from several Muslim majority countries. Japanese Prime Minister Abe is currently visiting the United States for his first meeting with President Trump. (Photo by Takashi Aoyama/Getty Images) TOKYO, JAPAN - FEBRUARY 12: Mason Hester from Mississippi poses for a photograph after the march to protest against the U.S. President Trump's executive order on immigration in Shibuya district on February 12, 2017 in Tokyo, Japan. Nearly 300 people participated in the march organized by the Alliance for an Inclusive America to protest against the U.S. President Donald Trumps executive order banning the immigration to the United States from several Muslim majority countries. Japanese Prime Minister Abe is currently visiting the United States for his first meeting with President Trump. (Photo by Takashi Aoyama/Getty Images) TOKYO, JAPAN - FEBRUARY 12: Protesters gather near the Yoyogi Park before the march to protest against the U.S. President Trump's executive order on immigration in Shibuya district on February 12, 2017 in Tokyo, Japan. Nearly 300 people participated in the march organized by the Alliance for an Inclusive America to protest against the U.S. President Donald Trumps executive order banning the immigration to the United States from several Muslim majority countries. Japanese Prime Minister Abe is currently visiting the United States for his first meeting with President Trump. (Photo by Takashi Aoyama/Getty Images) Americans residents in Tokyo and other expatriates march with placards to protest against U.S. President Donald Trump's executive order, travel ban, banning travelers from seven predominantly Muslim countries from entering the United States, in Tokyo, Japan on Sunday, February 12, 2017. (Photo by Richard Atrero de Guzman/NurPhoto via Getty Images) Americans residents in Tokyo and other expatriates march with placards to protest against U.S. President Donald Trump's executive order, travel ban, banning travelers from seven predominantly Muslim countries from entering the United States, in Tokyo, Japan on Sunday, February 12, 2017. (Photo by Richard Atrero de Guzman/NurPhoto via Getty Images) Foreign protesters in Tokyo posed for photo with their placards during a rally against U.S. President Donald Trump's executive order, travel ban, banning travelers from seven predominantly Muslim countries from entering the United States, in Tokyo, Japan on Sunday, February 12, 2017. (Photo by Richard Atrero de Guzman/NurPhoto via Getty Images) Foreign protesters in Tokyo posed for photo with their placards during a protest against U.S. President Donald Trump's executive order, travel ban, banning travelers from seven predominantly Muslim countries from entering the United States, in Tokyo, Japan on Sunday, February 12, 2017. (Photo by Richard Atrero de Guzman/NurPhoto via Getty Images) Americans residents in Tokyo posed for photo with their placards during a protest against U.S. President Donald Trump's executive order, travel ban, banning travelers from seven predominantly Muslim countries from entering the United States, in Tokyo, Japan on Sunday, February 12, 2017. (Photo by Richard Atrero de Guzman/NurPhoto via Getty Images) TOKYO, JAPAN - FEBRUARY 12: People gather near the Yoyogi park before the march to protest against the U.S. President Trump's executive order on immigration in Shibuya district on February 12, 2017 in Tokyo, Japan. Nearly 300 people participated in the march organized by the Alliance for an Inclusive America to protest against the U.S. President Donald Trumps executive order banning the immigration to the United States from several Muslim majority countries. Japanese Prime Minister Abe is currently visiting the United States for his first meeting with President Trump. (Photo by Takashi Aoyama/Getty Images) Americans residents in Tokyo and other expatriates march with placards to protest against U.S. President Donald Trump's executive order, travel ban, banning travelers from seven predominantly Muslim countries from entering the United States, in Tokyo, Japan on Sunday, February 12, 2017. (Photo by Richard Atrero de Guzman/NurPhoto via Getty Images) American residents in Tokyo and other expatriates march with placards to protest against U.S. President Donald Trump's executive order, travel ban, banning travelers from seven predominantly Muslim countries from entering the United States, in Tokyo, Japan on Sunday, February 12, 2017. (Photo by Richard Atrero de Guzman/NurPhoto via Getty Images) American residents in Tokyo and other expatriates march with placards to protest against U.S. President Donald Trump's executive order, travel ban, banning travelers from seven predominantly Muslim countries from entering the United States, in Tokyo, Japan on Sunday, February 12, 2017. (Photo by Richard Atrero de Guzman/NurPhoto via Getty Images) TOKYO, JAPAN - FEBRUARY 12: A protest march and rally organised by the Alliance for an Inclusive America group against the perceived anti-Muslim and anti-foreigner immigration policies of President Donald Trump, on February 12, 2017 in Tokyo, Japan. The Alliance of an Inclusive America is a multi-faith non-partisan group. About 250 Americans, other ex-pats and japanese people took part in the march to show people around the world they reject the Executive Order President Trump enacted at the end of January, indefinitely suspending the resettlement of Syrian refugees and temporarily banning people from seven majority Muslim countries from entering the United States. The Alliance of an Inclusive America is a multi-faith non-partisan group. About 250 Americans, other ex-pats and japanese people took part in the march to show people around the world they reject the Executive Order President Trump enacted at the end of January, indefinitely suspending the resettlement of Syrian refugees and temporarily banning people from seven majority Muslim countries from entering the United States.
